title: Canada and Belgium PPC and trade

content.description:
Include correctly labeled diagrams, if useful or required, in explaining your answers. A correctly labeled diagram must have all axes and curves clearly labeled and must show directional changes. If the question prompts you to “Calculate,” you must show how you arrived at your final answer.

Canada and Belgium are trading partners. Both countries have the same amount of resources and can produce carrots and/or beets. The table below shows the maximum number of units of carrots or beets that can be produced by each country. Assume constant opportunity costs in both countries.

Carrots
 Beets

Canada

Belgium
 <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Assume that prior to trade, Canada is producing <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units of carrots and <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units of beets. What can you conclude about the use of resources in Canada? Explain using the production possibilities curve model.

(b) Which country has the comparative advantage in the production of beets? Explain using numbers.

(c) Now assume each country specializes in the production of the good in which it has a comparative advantage, and the terms of trade are <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> unit of carrots for <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units of beets. Will Canada gain from trade? Explain.

(d) Suppose the maximum production of carrots in Canada decreases. How will this affect Canada’s opportunity cost of producing beets? Explain.

(e) Assume Canada’s civilian working-age population is <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> million, the labor force participation rate in Canada is <math alttext="75%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the unemployment rate is <math alttext="20%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the number of employed people in Canada. Show your work.
content.question: Respond to all parts of the question.
